title: Double slit - wave frequency and 60 micron slits

content.question: An electromagnetic wave, which may or may not be visible light, is incident on two narrow slits separated by a distance of <math alttext="60 micrometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>60</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>μ</mi><mtext>m</mtext></math>, as shown in the figure. An interference pattern is formed to the right of the slits. At a distance of <math alttext="0.50 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.50</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></math> from the slits, the distance from the pattern’s central intensity maximum to the adjacent maximum is <math alttext="0.010 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.010</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></math>. What is the approximate frequency of the electromagnetic wave?

choices.label: <math alttext="1.2 times 10 raised to the negative sixth power hertz" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.2</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>Hz</mtext></math>

<math alttext="6.0 times 10 raised to the negative fifth power hertz" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>6.0</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></msup><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>Hz</mtext></math>

<math alttext="5.0 times 10 to the twelfth power hertz" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5.0</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>12</mn></msup><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>Hz</mtext></math>

<math alttext="2.5 times 10 to the fourteenth power hertz" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.5</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>14</mn></msup><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>Hz</mtext></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="2.5 times 10 to the fourteenth power hertz" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.5</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>14</mn></msup><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>Hz</mtext></math>

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
